metadata.name: Potentially Suspicious Rundll32.EXE Execution of UDL File
metadata.comment: Detects the execution of rundll32.exe with the oledb32.dll library to open a UDL file. Threat actors can abuse this technique as a phishing vector to capture authentication credentials or other sensitive data.

batch.sql: SELECT * FROM process_activity WHERE time BETWEEN CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() AND (activity_id = 1 AND endswith(lower(process.parent_process.name), lower('\\\\explorer.exe')) AND endswith(lower(process.name), lower('\\\\rundll32.exe')) AND lower(process.file.name) = lower('rundll32.exe') AND contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('oledb32.dll')) AND contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(',opendslfile ')) AND contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('\\\\users*\\\\downloads\\\\')) AND endswith(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('.udl')))

output.summary: Detects the execution of rundll32.exe with the oledb32.dll library to open a UDL file. Threat actors can abuse this technique as a phishing vector to capture authentication credentials or other sensitive data.

metadata.objective: False positive: UDL files serve as a convenient and flexible tool for managing and testing database connections in various development and administrative scenarios. Reference: https://trustedsec.com/blog/oops-i-udld-it-again
